title: Paige Rawl Remains 'Positive' While Living With HIV
teaser: Paige Rawl grew up enduring intense bullying due to her HIV status. Her new memoir recounts the journey.
contentencoded:
Growing up in Indiana, Paige Rawl was a good student, played soccer, and entered the occasional beauty pageant. She was also HIV positive: her mother got the diagnosis when Rawl was a toddler.

But despite her daily medication regimen, she was a pretty typical kid.

Until middle school, when Rawl told her best friend about her HIV status. The word spread and a bullying campaign began: Rawl was dubbed “PAIDS” by her schoolmates, received anonymous notes and was dropped by all of her friends. School administrators were unresponsive and the stress grew to such a point that Rawl began developing physical symptoms.

“I was having stress induced seizures, I lost about 20 pounds, my hair began to fall out, I also was catatonic,” Rawl told Here & Now’s Robin Young. She even contemplated suicide.

Through counseling, a more supportive high school and the friendships of others in the HIV-AIDS community, Rawl eventually found the strength to not only bring a lawsuit against her former school, but to become an AIDS educator and an anti-bullying activist. She’s now published “Positive,”a memoir written with Ali Benjamin.
